title: GERD and Food: Calming the Burn

content: Have you ever felt a burning sensation rising in your chest after a big meal? More than 1 in 5 adults in the U.S. experience gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), a condition where stomach acid frequently flows back into the esophagus. While medications can help, diet and lifestyle factors can both play huge roles in managing your symptoms long term. Here’s what you need to know about GERD and nutrition, plus practical tips to keep reflux at bay.
GERD happens when the lower esophageal sphincter (the muscle separating your stomach from your esophagus) doesn’t close properly. That allows acid to escape upward, causing symptoms like:
Occasional heartburn isn’t unusual, but when it occurs more than twice a week or interferes with daily life, it may be GERD.

bullets: Heartburn (a burning feeling in the chest or throat)
Regurgitation of food or sour liquid
Trouble swallowing
A sensation of a lump in the throat

content: Not everyone experiences symptoms after eating foods that are listed below. Instead of limiting all of the foods listed, it is worth trying out some of these foods in varying amounts to assess your personal tolerance and thresholds.

Keeping a food and symptom journal can help you pinpoint your personal triggers. It is recommended to work with a registered dietitian specializing in digestive conditions to best support you on troubleshooting your symptoms.
Instead of singular foods, ensuring that your meals are consistently balanced throughout the day is helpful and may even help calm reflux. Here are some components to include on your balanced plate:
bullets: Spicy foods (chili peppers, hot sauces)
Fried and fatty foods, which slow stomach emptying
Tomatoes and citrus fruits, both high in acid
Onions and garlic
Chocolate, which can relax the esophageal sphincter
Peppermint (including teas, mints, and gums)
Coffee, alcohol, and carbonated drinks
Fiber-rich grains, like oatmeal, brown rice, quinoa, and whole wheat bread
Fruits with less acidity, like bananas, melons, watermelon, etc.
Lean proteins, like grilled chicken, turkey, or fish, instead of fried or fatty meats
Vegetables like green beans, carrots, broccoli, and leafy greens
Low-fat dairy (milk, yogurt, cheese) or plant-based alternatives (if full-fat versions worsen your reflux)

sections.heading: Don’t Overlook the Timing of Your Meals and Trigger Foods
content: Digestion can slow down later in the day, especially in the evening, which can worsen GERD symptoms because it increases the chance of stomach acid refluxing into the esophagus. This happens partly because the body's metabolism is less active at night, and common evening eating habits like eating large meals, eating close to bedtime, or eating fatty, fried, or spicy foods can further delay gastric emptying and put pressure on the lower esophageal sphincter (LES).
Some tips on managing meal timings, if they are your personal triggers:
GERD isn’t just about food — it’s also influenced by lifestyle and health factors. Here are some significant non-nutrition players that can worsen your GERD, even if you are eating a balanced diet.
bullets: Avoid large meals and trigger foods in the evening
Set a "cut-off" time for eating before bed
Allow two to three hours to digest your food before lying down
Smoking. It weakens the esophageal sphincter.
High stress levels. Stress doesn’t cause GERD, but it can worsen symptoms. Relaxation strategies like deep breathing, yoga, or walking may help.

Sleeping position. During sleep, the esophageal sphincter muscle relaxes, making it easier for stomach acid to flow back up. Propping up your head on pillows or using a wedge pillow can help prevent acid from flowing back up.

sections.heading: When to See a Doctor
content: If dietary and lifestyle changes aren’t enough, talk with your health care provider. They may recommend medications such as antacids, H2 blockers, or proton pump inhibitors. Seek medical attention right away if you experience chest pain, unintentional weight loss, or difficulty swallowing, as these can signal more serious issues.

Managing GERD doesn’t mean giving up all your favorite foods forever. It’s about noticing patterns, making appropriate substitutions and lifestyle adjustments, and creating habits that keep reflux in check.
Understanding your personal nutrition and lifestyle factors impacting your GERD symptoms will help you take control and feel more comfortable after meals.
